Although he had to resign as Prime Minister, Löfven continues to be an influential figure in the Swedish Social Democratic Party and in Swedish politics in general.
J\u00e1nos \u00c1der:
János Áder is a Hungarian politician and lawyer born on May 9, 1959, in the city of Csorna, Hungary.  Since May 10, 2012, he has held the position of President of the Republic of Hungary. 

Áder graduated from Eötvös Loránd University in 1984 with a degree in environmental law specializing in environmental law.  He began his political career in the 1980s as a member of the Hungarian Communist Party, but after the fall of the socialist regime in 1989, he joined the Democratic Forum of the Liberal Party (MDF). 

In 1990, he was elected a member of the Hungarian Parliament and became President of the MDF Parliamentary Group in 1994.  Since then, he has been an active politician in the Hungarian scene and has held several important positions in his career. 

In 1998, Áder was appointed Minister of the Environment in Viktor Orbán's government.  During his tenure, he focused on promoting policies to protect the environment and promote sustainable development. János Áder is known for his dedication to environmental protection and commitment to sustainability.  He has emphasized the importance of individual and collective responsibility in preserving our planet and has promoted initiatives to address climate change. 

In summary, János Áder is a Hungarian politician and lawyer who has played an important role in Hungarian and European politics.  His commitment to environmental protection and sustainability has made him a prominent figure in the fight against climate change.
Alexander Lukashenko:
Alexandr Lukashenko is a politician and former president of Belarus.  He was born on August 30, 1954 in Kopys, in the then Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic. 

Lukashenko graduated as an Agronomist from the Mogilev Agricultural School in 1975 and later obtained a master's degree in Agriculture from the Belarusian Agricultural Academy in 1985. Throughout his career, Lukashenko has been subject to sanctions by the European Union and the United States due to his authoritarian policies and human rights violations.  However, he has maintained control of power in Belarus for over two decades, establishing himself as one of the longest-serving leaders in the region.
Heinz Fischer:
Heinz Fischer was born on October 9, 1938 in Graz, Austria.  Coming from a working-class family, he grew up in a modest but affectionate environment.  From a young age, he showed interest in politics and social justice, which led him to become one of Austria's most prominent politicians.

Simonetta Sommaruga:
Simonetta Sommaruga is a Swiss politician born on May 14, 1960 in Zug, Switzerland.  She is a member of the Swiss Socialist Party and has held several important positions in the Swiss government.

Rosen Plevneliev:
Rosen Plevneliev was born on May 14, 1964 in the city of Gotse Delchev, Bulgaria.  Coming from a modest family, Rosen had to work hard from a young age to help support his family.

Muhammadu Buhari:
Muhammadu Buhari was born on 17 December 1942 in Daura, Nigeria.  He is a Nigerian politician and military officer, currently serving as the President of Nigeria since 29 May 2015. 

Buhari belongs to the Fulani ethnic group, one of the largest and most prominent ethnic groups in Nigeria.  He began his education at Daura primary school and later attended the Government College Katsina, obtaining his West African School Certificate in 1961.  He then joined the Nigerian Military Academy in Kaduna and graduated in 1963. 

After completing his military training, Buhari joined the Nigerian army and began his military career.  During the Nigerian Civil War (1967-1970), he was one of the prominent officers who fought against Biafra.  His bravery and leadership on the battlefield earned him several promotions and recognitions. 

In 1983, Buhari led a successful military coup, overthrowing the civilian government of President Shehu Shagari and assuming power as head of state.  During his tenure, Buhari implemented measures to combat corruption, improve morale and discipline in the country, but he was also criticized for human rights violations.

During his time in prison, Buhari began to be seen as a symbol of resistance against corruption and bad governance. 

Following his release, Buhari retired from the army and turned to politics.  He founded the Congress for Progressive Change (CPC) and ran for the Nigerian presidency in 2003, 2007, and 2011, without success.

Throughout his political career, Muhammadu Buhari has been recognized for his integrity and strong leadership.  However, he has also faced criticism for his authoritarian approach and response to financial and security challenges in Nigeria.

Hailemariam Desalegn:
Hailemariam Desalegn was born on July 19, 1965 in the village of Boloso Sore, in the Wolayta region of Ethiopia.  Coming from a humble family, he worked hard to overcome economic difficulties and achieve a quality education. 

Desalegn started his primary education in Boloso Sore, and later attended high school in Wolayta Sodo.  His academic talent earned him a scholarship to study civil engineering at Addis Ababa University, where he graduated with excellent grades in 1988. 

After completing his studies, Desalegn joined the Ethiopia Construction and Rehabilitation Agency (ECRA) as an engineer.  During his time at ECRA, he demonstrated outstanding project management skills and was quickly promoted to positions of higher responsibility.

During his tenure, he implemented important infrastructure projects, such as road construction and transportation system improvement. In 2010, Desalegn was appointed Minister of Foreign Affairs of Ethiopia, and the following year, he became a high-ranking member of the ruling party, the Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF).

During his tenure, Desalegn focused on promoting economic growth, improving education, and fostering peace and stability in the Horn of Africa region.

Abdel Fattah el-Sisi:
Abdel Fattah el-Sisi was born on November 19, 1954, in Gamaleya, a small village in the Nile Delta, Egypt.  Coming from a modest family, he grew up in a rural environment and soon developed a strong sense of patriotism and determination to serve his country. 

After completing his primary and secondary education, el-Sisi joined the Egyptian Military Academy in 1977.  During his time at the academy, he demonstrated his commitment and exceptional abilities, which allowed him to graduate in 1977 as a second lieutenant in the Combat Engineers Corps. 

Throughout his military career, el-Sisi proved to be a natural leader and quickly rose through the ranks.  He specialized in combat operations and military strategy, and earned a Master's degree in Military Sciences in 1987. 

However, it was in the political arena where el-Sisi gained fame and international recognition.  In January 2011, during the so-called Arab Spring, el-Sisi became the Director of the Egyptian Military Academy.  During this time, the country was facing a major political and social crisis, and el-Sisi was directly involved in the events that led to the fall of President Hosni Mubarak. 

In 2012, el-Sisi became the head of Egyptian military intelligence and was later appointed Minister of Defense by President Mohamed Morsi. In 2014, after a presidential election in which el-Sisi received broad popular support, he officially became the President of Egypt.  During his tenure, el-Sisi has implemented economic and political reforms, and has been deeply involved in the fight against terrorism and the stabilization of the region amid growing tensions. 

El-Sisi's leadership has sparked controversy and criticism for his authoritarian approach and repression of freedom of expression and human rights in Egypt.  Although he has been praised for his firm stance against extremism and his success in maintaining internal stability in Egypt.

Joseph Kabila:
Joseph Kabila was born on June 4, 1971 in Hewa Bora, a small village in the province of Katanga, in the Democratic Republic of Congo.  His father, Laurent-Désiré Kabila, was a rebel leader and president of the country at that time. 

He began his education in Lubumbashi, where he studied at a local primary school.  Later, he moved to Tanzania to continue his studies at the French Technical Institute of Lubumbashi.  During his time in Tanzania, Kabila witnessed the difficult political conditions in which the Congolese lived and his father's struggle to liberate his country from dictatorship. 

In 1996, Kabila's father led the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (AFDL), a coalition of rebel groups seeking to overthrow the dictator Mobutu Sese Seko.  Joseph joined the AFDL and played an active role in the fight against the regime. 

In 1997, the AFDL succeeded and Laurent-Désiré Kabila became the president of the Democratic Republic of Congo, previously known as Zaire.  Joseph held various positions in the government, including Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces. 

In January 2001, after the assassination of his father, Joseph Kabila assumed the presidency of the country at the age of 29, becoming the youngest head of state in Africa at that time.  During his tenure, Kabila faced numerous challenges, including fighting rebel militias in the east of the country and reintegrating former combatants into society. 

In 2006, Kabila was formally elected as president in the country's first democratic elections in over four decades.  He was reelected in 2011 and remained in office until 2019, when he handed over the presidency to Félix Tshisekedi after the general elections. 

Throughout his presidency, Kabila was criticized for his political management and alleged corruption.  In addition, the country experienced a series of armed conflicts and social problems. 

Despite the controversies surrounding his presidency, Joseph Kabila remained an influential figure in Congolese politics.  After leaving the presidential office, he continues to be a key figure behind the scenes and is the leader of his political party, the People's Party for Reconstruction and Democracy (PPRD). 

Joseph Kabila's life is intertwined with the modern history of the Democratic Republic of Congo and his legacy continues to be debated in the country.
Jakaya Kikwete:
Jakaya Mrisho Kikwete was born on October 7, 1950 in Msoga, a small village in the Bagamoyo district, in the territory of Tanganyika, which is now part of Tanzania.  He was the fourth President of Tanzania, serving from 2005 to 2015. 

Kikwete was born into a humble family and received his education in local schools.  After completing high school, he furthered his education at Tanga High School, where he obtained his diploma. 

In 1972, Kikwete joined the Chama Cha Mapinduzi (CCM) party, the ruling party at that time.  He began his political career by working as the secretary of the Bagamoyo district committee.  His dedication and political skills led him to hold various positions within the party. 

In the 1980s, Kikwete became a Member of Parliament and served as Assistant Minister in the Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning.  In 1994, he was appointed Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Cooperation.  During his tenure, he played a crucial role in resolving conflicts in neighboring countries such as Burundi and the Democratic Republic of Congo. 

In 2005, Kikwete was elected President of Tanzania, succeeding Benjamin Mkapa.  During his presidency, Kikwete focused on fighting corruption, improving healthcare and education, and driving the country's economic growth. 

Under his leadership, Tanzania experienced significant economic growth and became one of the most attractive destinations for foreign investment in East Africa.  Additionally, Kikwete became an advocate for global issues, such as combating climate change and promoting peace and security in the region. 

After serving two terms as president, Kikwete left office in 2015.  Since then, he has continued to work on various projects and international organizations, including his role as a mediator in the Burundi conflict. 

Jakaya Kikwete's political career has been characterized by his dedication to public service and commitment to the development and stability of Tanzania and Africa as a whole.  His leadership has been recognized nationally and internationally, making him one of the most influential and respected political figures in the region.
Jacob Zuma:
Jacob Zuma was born on April 12, 1942 in Nkandla, a small village in the South African province of KwaZulu-Natal.  He was the eldest son of a policeman and a housewife and received a modest education in a rural environment. 

From a young age, Zuma showed an interest in politics and joined the African National Congress (ANC) in the 1950s.  He actively participated in the fight against apartheid, which led to his arrest and imprisonment on several occasions. 

Following Nelson Mandela's release in 1990, Zuma emerged as a prominent figure within the ANC and held various important positions in the South African government.  He served as Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1999 to 2005 and later as Vice President of South Africa in 2005. 

However, Zuma's political life was not without controversy.  In 2005, he was accused of corruption related to a controversial arms deal, which led to his dismissal as vice president in 2005. 

Despite facing numerous accusations of corruption and mismanagement, Zuma managed to become the President of South Africa in 2009, after a controversial process within the ANC.  During his term, his government was marked by numerous scandals, as well as economic stagnation and high levels of unemployment. 

Finally, in 2018, Zuma was forced to resign as president after the ANC lost confidence in him and faced a vote of no confidence in Parliament.  Since then, he has been the subject of multiple investigations and trials for corruption and misappropriation of public funds. 

Despite his controversies, Zuma remains an influential figure in South African politics and retains strong support among some sectors of the population.  His legacy continues to be a subject of debate in South Africa, where many question his leadership and accountability during his presidency.
Uhuru Kenyatta:
Uhuru Kenyatta is a Kenyan politician and businessman, born on October 26, 1961 in Nairobi, Kenya.  He is the current president of Kenya and the leader of the political party Jubilee Alliance. 

Kenyatta comes from a prominent political family in Kenya.  He is the son of Kenya's first president, Jomo Kenyatta, and the political leader and civil rights activist, Mama Ngina Kenyatta.  From a young age, Uhuru Kenyatta was exposed to politics and government affairs. 

After completing his primary and secondary education in Kenya, Kenyatta studied economics at St.  Mary's University in Maryland, United States.  Later, he obtained a bachelor's degree in Economics and Political Science at the University of Nairobi. 

Upon returning to Kenya, Kenyatta became increasingly interested in politics and began to get involved in various family businesses.  In 1997, he was nominated as a presidential candidate by the Kenya African National Union (KANU) political party.  However, he was defeated in the elections, but that did not discourage him. 

In 2001, Kenyatta was appointed Minister of Tourism and Wildlife in the government of President Daniel arap Moi.  During his tenure, Kenyatta implemented several successful policies to promote tourism in Kenya, which significantly contributed to the country's economy. 

After Moi's retirement, Kenyatta continued to play an active role in Kenyan politics.  In 2013, he ran as a presidential candidate under the Jubilee Alliance political party and was elected as the fourth president of Kenya.  His administration focused on promoting unity and economic development in the country. 

Throughout his political career, Kenyatta has faced various challenges and controversies.  In 2011, he was charged by the International Criminal Court with crimes against humanity in connection with the post-election violence of 2007 in Kenya.  However, in 2014, the Court dropped the charges against him due to lack of evidence. 

Outside of politics, Kenyatta is also known for his business success.  He has owned several companies in sectors such as agriculture, transportation, and banking. 

In summary, Uhuru Kenyatta is a prominent politician in Kenya, the son of the country's first president.  His political career has been marked by successes and controversies, and he currently serves as the president of Kenya.  Despite challenges, Kenyatta has demonstrated his dedication to the economic development and unity of his country.
Yoweri Museveni:
Yoweri Kaguta Museveni was born on September 15, 1944 in Ntungamo, a small village in the British territory of Uganda.  Son of cattle farmers, he grew up in a rural environment and firsthand experienced the challenges and difficulties of life in the countryside. 

After completing his primary and secondary education, Museveni obtained a scholarship to attend the University of Dar es Salaam in Tanzania, where he studied economics and political science.  During his time there, he actively engaged in the student movement and began to embrace revolutionary ideas of fighting against oppression and poverty in Africa. 

In 1970, Museveni founded the National Resistance Front (FRONASA), a guerrilla group that opposed the dictatorial regime of Idi Amin in Uganda.  His determination and leadership skills soon made him a prominent figure within the resistance movement. 

After the fall of Amin's regime in 1979, Museveni joined the transitional government.  However, he quickly became disillusioned with the lack of progress and rampant corruption within the existing political system.  Consequently, he decided to form his own movement, the National Resistance Movement of Uganda (NRM), with the aim of establishing a government based on a new model of democracy and economic development. 

Museveni's opportunity came in January 1986 when he successfully led a military rebellion against President Milton Obote and assumed power in Uganda.  Since taking office, Museveni has been the president of Uganda for over 30 years, being one of the longest-serving African leaders. 

During his presidency, Museveni has implemented a series of political and economic reforms aimed at modernizing and stabilizing the country.  His focus on security and stability has led to significant improvements in areas such as education, health, and infrastructure. 

However, Museveni's presidency has also been subject to criticism and controversies.  He has been accused of human rights violations, suppressing political opposition, and clinging to power through controversial elections.  These controversies have overshadowed his legacy and sparked debates about the need for a democratic transition in Uganda. 

Despite the criticisms, Museveni has shown political skill and resilience, winning multiple elections and maintaining his position as an influential leader in Africa.  His political influence and leadership have left a lasting mark on Uganda and East African politics as a whole.
Abdelaziz Bouteflika:
Abdelaziz Bouteflika was born on March 2, 1937 in Oujda, Morocco.  He was the youngest of eight siblings in a family of Berber origin.  At an early age, his family moved to Tlemcen, Algeria, where he grew up and acquired his primary and secondary education. 

From a young age, Bouteflika showed a great interest in politics and joined the National Liberation Movement (FLN), which fought for Algeria's independence from French colonial rule.  During the Algerian War of Independence (1954-1962), he actively participated in political and military activities. 

After Algeria gained its independence in 1962, Bouteflika became a prominent member of the FLN party and the Algerian government.  He held several high-level positions, including Minister of Youth and Tourism in 1963 and Minister of State in charge of Western Sahara Affairs in 1977. 

However, his greatest achievement came in 1999 when he ran for the office of President of Algeria.  He won the elections by a large majority and assumed office on April 27 of that year.  His presidential term was characterized by his focus on national reconciliation and the reconstruction of a country devastated by a long civil war in the 1990s. 

Bouteflika implemented a series of reforms aimed at promoting economic, political, and social stability in Algeria.  He also promoted the development of the country's infrastructure, the improvement of the educational system, and the attraction of foreign investment.  Under his leadership, Algeria achieved sustained economic growth and became a key player in the North African region. 

However, his term was also marked by controversy and criticism.  His government was accused of corruption and authoritarianism, leading to popular protests in 2011 and 2019 demanding his resignation.  In 2013, he suffered a stroke that left him with mobility and speech problems, raising doubts about his ability to govern. 

Finally, in April 2019, due to escalating protests and popular pressure, Bouteflika announced his resignation from the presidency.  His political legacy and his impact remain the subject of debate and analysis in Algeria. 

Abdelaziz Bouteflika passed away on September 17, 2021, at the age of 84, leaving behind a mixed and controversial legacy in Algeria's political and social history.
Omar al-Bashir:
Omar al-Bashir was born on January 1, 1944 in Hosh Bannaga, a small village in the Shendi region of Sudan.  Coming from a family of farmers, he grew up in a rural environment and spent much of his youth herding sheep and camels. 

Despite his humble origins, al-Bashir showed great intelligence and ambition from an early age.  After completing his primary education in his hometown, he moved to the city of Khartoum to continue his education.  There, he joined the Khartoum Military Institute and graduated as an army officer in 1966. 

During the early years of his military career, al-Bashir participated in several missions abroad, including the deployment of Sudanese forces in the Yom Kippur War in 1973.  His experience and skills as a soldier gained recognition and he was promoted to higher positions of responsibility in the army. 

In 1989, al-Bashir led a successful military coup that overthrew the government of Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi.  This event marked the beginning of his tenure as president of Sudan, a position he would hold for almost three decades.  During his rule, al-Bashir implemented a series of controversial policies that generated both praise and criticism. 

One of the most notable aspects of his rule was the war in Darfur, a region in western Sudan.  This war, which began in 2003, was marked by widespread human rights violations and accusations of genocide by the Sudanese government.  Al-Bashir was charged with crimes against humanity by the International Criminal Court in 2009 and an arrest warrant was issued against him. 

In addition to facing accusations of human rights abuses, al-Bashir also faced internal challenges in his own country.  Massive protests in 2018 and 2019 demanded his resignation and a democratic change in Sudan.  Finally, in April 2019, after months of pressure from civil society and the army, al-Bashir was overthrown and arrested by the Sudanese army. 

Since his arrest, al-Bashir has faced several trials and has been convicted of corruption and other crimes.  Although his government was marked by controversy and violence, his influence on Sudan's history is undeniable.  Omar al-Bashir, the former president of Sudan, left a complex and polarizing legacy that continues to be a subject of debate.
Abdelilah Benkirane:
Abdelilah Benkirane was born on April 26, 1954 in Rabat, Morocco.  He is a Moroccan politician who served as Secretary General of the Justice and Development Party (PJD) from 2008 to 2018.  Additionally, he held the position of Prime Minister of Morocco from 2011 to 2017. 

Benkirane comes from a modest and humble family and grew up in a political environment.  His father, Ahmed Benkirane, was a prominent member of the Moroccan nationalist movement and his grandfather, Mohammed Benkjirane, was a prominent member of the resistance movement against French colonialism. 

Abdelilah Benkirane began his political career in the 1970s when he joined student and labor movements in Morocco.  His leadership skills and political abilities became evident quickly, and he became a prominent figure in the Moroccan Human Rights Movement. 

In 1991, Benkirane co-founded the Justice and Development Party (PJD), a moderate Islamic political party that seeks to combine Islamic principles with democracy and economic development.  The PJD became a major political party in Morocco, and Benkirane became one of its main leaders. 

In 2008, Benkirane was elected as Secretary General of the PJD, and under his leadership, the party made significant progress in the 2011 parliamentary elections.  Following the electoral success, King Mohammed VI appointed Benkirane as Prime Minister. 

During his tenure as Prime Minister, Benkirane implemented numerous economic and social reforms, such as modernizing the public administration, fighting corruption, and promoting foreign investment.  He also worked closely with leaders of other political parties to achieve greater political stability in the country. 

However, Benkirane's term was also marked by challenges and controversies.  In 2016, talks to form a new government stalled due to ideological and political differences between the PJD and other political parties.  These tensions led to Benkirane's dismissal as Prime Minister in 2017. 

Despite his dismissal, Abdelilah Benkirane remains an important figure in Moroccan politics and continues to actively participate in the PJD.  His experience and political skills make him one of the most influential leaders in Morocco, and his legacy as Prime Minister and Secretary General of the PJD has left a lasting mark on Moroccan politics.
Jos\u00e9 Eduardo dos Santos:
José Eduardo dos Santos was born on August 28, 1942 in the city of Sambizanga, in the Portuguese colony of Angola.  He was the fourth President of the Republic of Angola, serving from 1979 until 2017, becoming one of the longest-serving leaders in Africa. 

Dos Santos was born into a humble family and spent his childhood in the Angolan capital, Luanda.  In his youth, he joined the People's Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA), an organization that advocated for Angola's independence from Portuguese colonial rule.  During the liberation struggle, Dos Santos stood out for his political skills and quickly rose through the ranks of the party. 

Following Angola's independence in 1975, the MPLA became the ruling party and Dos Santos held various important positions in the government.  In 1979, after the death of Angola's first President, Agostinho Neto, Dos Santos was appointed as his successor. 

Throughout his tenure, Dos Santos sought to consolidate unity and stability in Angola.  However, he also faced several challenges, such as the civil war that took place in the country from 1975 to 2002.  During this conflict, Angola faced insurgencies from various rebel groups, as well as intervention from foreign forces. 

Despite the difficulties, Dos Santos' government succeeded in rebuilding the country's economy, focusing on the oil industry and diversifying other sectors such as agriculture and tourism.  However, his administration also faced criticism, particularly due to lack of transparency in the management of national resources and the high level of corruption prevailing in Angola. 

In 2017, Dos Santos announced that he would not run for re-election in the presidential elections, marking the end of his nearly four-decade-long tenure.  He was succeeded by João Lourenço, who took over the presidency in September of that year. 

After leaving office, Dos Santos retired from active politics and has been involved in charity projects and promoting development in Angola.  Despite the criticisms and controversies surrounding his government, his legacy as a leader and his contribution to Angola's independence and reconstruction are fundamental parts of the country's history.
Filipe Nyusi:
Filipe Jacinto Nyusi is a Mozambican politician and military officer, born on February 9, 1959 in Namau, Mozambique.  Since January 15, 2015, he has served as the fourth president of the Republic of Mozambique. 

Nyusi grew up in the province of Cabo Delgado, a rural region located in northern Mozambique.  As a teenager, he joined the national liberation struggle against Portuguese colonial rule in his country.  He was actively involved in the Mozambique Liberation Front (FRELIMO), which eventually achieved Mozambique's independence in 1975. 

After independence, Nyusi joined the Mozambique Defence Armed Forces (FADM) and became a military pilot.  He also received training abroad, particularly in the Soviet Union and Cape Verde, where he acquired knowledge in engineering and technical management. 

Throughout his military career, Nyusi rose through the ranks and held various leadership positions.  He served as the commander of the Mozambique Air Force and later held the position of Secretary General of the Ministry of Defence. 

In 2014, he ran as the FRELIMO presidential candidate for the general elections and won both the nomination in his party and the general elections.  On January 15, 2015, he took office as President of the Republic of Mozambique. 

His presidency has been marked by a series of challenges, including reconstruction and stabilization after decades of armed conflict in the country.  Nyusi has worked to promote economic development, improve infrastructure, and foster peace and reconciliation. 

In addition to his role as president, Nyusi has been active on the international stage, representing Mozambique at various international summits and forums.  He has been recognized for his leadership and commitment to peace and stability in Africa. 

In summary, Filipe Nyusi is a Mozambican politician and military officer who has dedicated much of his life to serving his country.  His leadership has been instrumental in the reconstruction and development of Mozambique, and he has demonstrated unwavering commitment to peace and stability in the region.
John Mahama:
John Dramani Mahama was born on November 29, 1958 in Damongo, a small city in the north of Ghana.  He is a Ghanaian politician who served as president of his country from 2012 to 2017. 

Mahama belongs to the Gonja ethnic group and grew up as the son of a successful politician and businessman.  He studied at the University of Ghana, where he obtained his Bachelor's degree in History in 1981.  Subsequently, he completed a Master's in Communication at the University of Ghana and a Master's in Public Administration at Harvard University.

During his time in Parliament, he held important positions such as Minister of Communications and Minister of Foreign Affairs.  He also served as Vice President of Ghana under President John Atta Mills from 2009 to 2012. 

In July 2012, following the unfortunate death of President Atta Mills, Mahama, as Vice President at that time, assumed the presidency of Ghana. During his tenure, Mahama implemented various policies to promote economic and social development in Ghana.  He introduced initiatives to improve infrastructure, including the construction of roads, hospitals, and schools.  He also fought against corruption and promoted transparency in government.

In the December 2016 general elections, Mahama sought re-election but was defeated by Nana Akufo-Addo, who became the new president of Ghana. 

After leaving the presidential office, Mahama has continued to be an influential figure in Ghanaian politics and in the NDC party.  In 2020, he ran again as the NDC's presidential candidate, but lost to Nana Akufo-Addo in the presidential elections. 

John Mahama is recognized for his leadership and commitment to Ghana's development.  Despite the difficulties, his legacy remains as an important figure in his country's politics.
Hery Rajaonarimampianina:
Hery Rajaonarimampianina was born on November 6, 1958 in Antsirabe, Madagascar.  After completing his secondary education in his hometown, he decided to study Agricultural Sciences at the University of Antananarivo.

Paul Biya:
Paul Biya was born on February 13, 1933, in Mvoméka’a, a small village in the South region of Cameroon.  Coming from a modest family, Biya is the son of Etienne Mvondo Assam and Anastasie Eyenga Elle, who worked as farmers. 

From a young age, Biya showed a great interest in education and politics.  After completing his primary education in his native village, he moved to the capital, Yaoundé, to attend the General Leclerc Primary and Secondary School.  Later, Biya obtained a scholarship to study at the Lycée Louis le Grand in Paris, France. 

In France, Biya continued to develop his love for learning and graduated with a Master's degree in Public Law and Administration from the University of Paris.  During his time in Paris, he also actively engaged in politics, participating in Cameroonian student groups and independence movements. 

After Cameroon's independence in 1960, Biya returned to his homeland and quickly became a prominent figure in politics.  He was appointed Secretary of State at the Presidency in 1962 and held various ministerial positions in the following years.  In 1975, Biya became Prime Minister and eventually, in 1982, he assumed the position of President of Cameroon, following the resignation of Ahmadou Ahidjo.

His tenure has been marked by controversies, as he has faced accusations of corruption, human rights violations, and political repression.  However, he has also implemented economic development policies and promoted stability in the country. 

With over four decades in power, Biya is one of the longest-serving presidents in Africa and has consolidated his leadership despite criticisms.  He is often credited with the ability to maintain unity in a diverse country, divided by ethnic and linguistic lines. 

Currently, Paul Biya remains an influential figure in Cameroonian politics and continues to lead the country.  At over 80 years old, his legacy is debated, with some praising his stability and economic development, while others criticize his authoritarianism and lack of democracy.
Alassane Ouattara:
Alassane Dramane Ouattara was born on January 1, 1942 in Dimbokro, Ivory Coast.  Coming from a family of Muslim descent, he grew up in a middle-class family and received a solid education. 

He began his studies in Armelia, a small town in northern Ivory Coast, and later moved to the capital, Abidjan, where he attended the prestigious Lycée Descartes to complete his secondary education.  He then moved to France, where he obtained a bachelor's degree in Economics from the University of Dijon and a master's degree in Political Science from the University of Paris. 

After completing his studies, Ouattara started a successful career at the International Monetary Fund (IMF), where he worked for over a decade in various African countries, including Cameroon and Guinea.  His experience at the IMF and his knowledge of economic affairs led him to become one of the most respected economists in the African continent. 

In 1990, Ouattara returned to Ivory Coast and joined the government as Prime Minister under the presidency of Félix Houphouët-Boigny.  During his tenure, he implemented austerity policies and significant economic reforms that helped stabilize the economy and attract foreign investment to the country. 

Unfortunately, his political career was interrupted in 1993 when a violent political struggle broke out in Ivory Coast and he was forced into exile.  During his exile, he continued to work as an economic advisor and advocated for political stability and economic development in Ivory Coast. 

In 2002, Ouattara returned to Ivory Coast and became the leader of the political party Rassemblement des Républicains (RDR).  After years of intense conflicts and political disputes in the country, he ran in the 2010 presidential elections and was declared the winner.  However, his victory was contested by the incumbent president, Laurent Gbagbo, leading to a political crisis and a civil war. 

After months of conflict, Ouattara finally took office as president in May 2011 and has since worked to rebuild Ivory Coast and promote national reconciliation.  During his presidency, he has promoted economic growth, political stability, and foreign investment in the country. 

Alassane Ouattara is considered a charismatic leader and a key figure in Ivorian politics.  He has successfully improved the country's political stability, revitalized its economy, and promoted greater regional integration in West Africa.  Through his leadership, Ouattara has worked to position Ivory Coast as a key player on the international stage and to continue improving the quality of life for its citizens.
Mahamadou Issoufou:
Mahamadou Issoufou is a Nigerien politician born on January 1, 1952 in the city of Dandadji, in the Dosso region, in Niger.  He comes from a modest family and received his primary and secondary education in his hometown.  He then moved to the capital, Niamey, to study at the University of Niger, where he obtained a degree in Economics. 

After graduating, Issoufou began a career in the Nigerien public sector, holding various positions in the Ministry of Finance and the National Institute of Statistics.  His ability in economic management and his commitment to his country's development led him to be appointed Minister of Mining and Energy in Seyni Kountché's government in 1989. 

Following Kountché's death in 1993, Issoufou founded and became the leader of the political party National Movement for the Development of Society (MNSD-Nassara).  He participated in the presidential elections of 1993, 1996, and 1999, but did not succeed in winning the presidency in any of them. 

Finally, in 2011, after a long political career and several attempts, Mahamadou Issoufou was elected President of Niger in the presidential elections.  During his government, he focused on improving the economy, promoting foreign investment, and implementing reforms to encourage growth and sustainable development. 

Issoufou also focused on improving education and health in his country.  He implemented programs to increase access to primary and secondary education, and expanded the healthcare network to ensure that Nigeriens had access to quality health services. 

In addition to his work at the national level, Issoufou has also played an important role in international politics.  He has been recognized for his leadership in the fight against terrorism and the promotion of stability in the Sahel region.  As part of his commitment to peace, Issoufou has been actively involved in mediating conflicts in neighboring countries, such as Mali and Burkina Faso. 

Mahamadou Issoufou has been reelected twice, in 2016 and 2021, thus demonstrating popular support for his leadership and policies.  His tenure has been characterized by his focus on economic and social development, as well as his defense of human rights and democracy in Niger. 

In summary, Mahamadou Issoufou is a prominent Nigerien politician who has dedicated his career to improving the living conditions of his fellow citizens.  His leadership has been acclaimed both nationally and internationally, and his legacy will endure in the history of Niger.
Michel Kafando:
Michel Kafando was born on August 18, 1942 in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso.  Throughout his life, he has stood out as a politician and diplomat, being a prominent figure in the fight for democracy and human rights in his country. 

Kafando received his primary and secondary education in Burkina Faso, and then moved to France to pursue his higher studies.  There, he obtained a Bachelor's degree in Law and Political Science from the University of Dijon. 

After completing his education, Kafando returned to Burkina Faso and began working in the civil service.  His diplomatic career began at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, where he held several important positions.  Subsequently, he became Burkina Faso's ambassador to various countries, including Algeria, the Soviet Union, and France. 

In 2014, the country experienced a popular uprising that led to the overthrow of the then President Blaise Compaoré, who had ruled for 27 years.  As a result of this uprising, Kafando was appointed as the transitional president and assumed office on November 17, 2014. 

During his term as transitional president, Kafando carried out important political and democratic reforms in Burkina Faso.  He established a national unity government and worked to restore the people's trust in the political system.  During his tenure, presidential and parliamentary elections were held, and a new president, Roch Marc Christian Kaboré, was elected in December 2015. 

After completing his term as transitional president, Kafando returned to his diplomatic career and served as the Special Representative of the United Nations Secretary-General for Burundi.  He has also been a tireless advocate for human rights and democracy in his country and throughout the African continent. 

Michel Kafando is recognized and respected both in Burkina Faso and internationally for his dedication and commitment to democracy and human rights.  His leadership during the transition and his contribution to peace and stability in his country make him an important figure in the history of Burkina Faso.
Ibrahim Boubacar Ke\u00efta:
Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta, known as IBK, was born on January 29, 1945 in Koutiala, Mali.  Coming from a Muslim family, Keïta grew up amidst the cultural and religious diversity of his country.  From a young age, he showed interest in politics and social justice, which would lead him to become one of the most influential leaders in Mali.

There, Keïta specialized in history and political science at the University of Bordeaux.  During his time in France, Keïta also joined the student movement and actively participated in protests for independence and civil rights in several African countries. 

After completing his education, Keïta returned to Mali and began working in the field of public administration.  He held various positions in the government, including Minister of Foreign Affairs and Minister of Defense, where he demonstrated his diplomatic skills and political management. 

In 2002, Keïta founded his own political party, the Rally for Mali (RPM), with the aim of promoting economic and social development in his country.  His vision and leadership led him to win the presidential elections in 2013, becoming the fifth president of Mali. 

During his presidency, Keïta faced numerous challenges, such as the conflict in northern Mali with rebel and terrorist groups.  He implemented policies to promote stability and development in the region, seeking peaceful solutions through dialogue and regional cooperation. 

However, his tenure was also marked by corruption and political instability, which led to massive protests in the country.  In August 2020, Keïta was overthrown by a military coup and was forced to resign as president. 

Despite the challenges faced during his time in office, Ibrahim Boubacar Keïta left a significant legacy in Malian politics.  He is recognized for his dedication and commitment to peace and stability in his country, as well as his efforts in the fight against terrorism and the promotion of socio-economic development. 

After his resignation, Keïta retired from active political life and devoted himself to writing his memoirs and working on development projects to improve the quality of life of Malian citizens.  His contribution to politics and his fight for a better Mali will be remembered and appreciated by future generations.
Barack Obama:
Barack Hussein Obama was born on August 4, 1961 in Honolulu, Hawaii.  He was the son of Barack Obama Sr. , a Kenyan economist, and Stanley Ann Dunham, an American anthropologist. 

During his youth, Obama lived in different places such as Hawaii and Indonesia, due to his mother marrying an Indonesian.  However, after returning to Hawaii to complete his high school education, he decided to attend college in the continental United States. 

Obama graduated in Political Science from Columbia University in 1983 and later moved to Chicago.  There, he worked as a community organizer in marginalized communities and got involved in local politics. 

In 1991, Obama enrolled in Harvard Law School, where he excelled academically and showed interest in social justice and civil rights issues.  After graduating, he worked as a lawyer and constitutional law professor at the University of Chicago. 

Obama's first step into national politics came in 1996 when he was elected to the Illinois State Senate.  Then, in 2004, he delivered a highly acclaimed speech at the Democratic National Convention, which gave him great visibility and allowed him to run for the position of United States Senator from the state of Illinois.  Obama won the election and became the only African American in the Senate at that time. 

Obama's political career reached a crucial point in 2008 when he announced his candidacy for the presidency of the United States.  During his campaign, Obama presented himself as an agent of change and emphasized the importance of uniting Americans through a message of hope and unity. 

On January 20, 2009, Barack Obama was sworn in as the 44th President of the United States, becoming the first African American to hold that office.  His presidency was marked by a series of challenges, such as the global financial and economic crisis, the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, and the implementation of the healthcare reform known as Obamacare. 

During his tenure, Obama promoted a liberal agenda, advocating for policies in areas such as civil rights, clean energy, education, and immigration reform.  Additionally, he called for the closure of the Guantanamo prison and signed the Paris climate agreement. 

In 2012, Obama was reelected as president and continued to implement his political vision.  However, his administration also faced criticisms and challenges, both domestically and internationally. 

At the end of his term in January 2017, Obama left a legacy in American history as the first African American president and the leader who drove significant political and social changes in the country.  Since then, he has continued his work as an activist and has written several books, including his autobiography "Dreams from My Father" and "A Promised Land. " His influence and legacy in American politics remain significant.
Dilma Rousseff:
Dilma Rousseff was born on December 14, 1947 in Belo Horizonte, Brazil.  From a young age, she showed a strong interest in politics and social justice, which led her to get involved in political activism during her university years. 

Rousseff graduated from the Federal University of Minas Gerais in Economics, and later obtained a master's degree in Economics from the University of Campinas.  After completing her studies, she began working for the Brazilian government in the field of economic policy. 

In the 1970s, Rousseff joined the armed struggle against the military dictatorship that ruled Brazil at that time.  She was arrested in 1970 and tortured during her detention.  After being released, she continued her political activism and joined the Democratic Labour Party. 

Her political career took off in the 2000s, when she was appointed Minister of Energy and later Minister of Mines and Energy.  In 2010, she became the Workers' Party candidate for the presidency of Brazil, with the backing of then President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva. 

In the 2010 presidential elections, Rousseff was elected as the first female president of Brazil, defeating opposition candidate José Serra.  During her term, she implemented policies aimed at reducing poverty and improving education and health in the country.  However, she also faced harsh criticism and protests due to economic problems and corruption cases in her government. 

In 2016, Rousseff underwent a political impeachment and was removed from office due to accusations of public accounting manipulation.  Michel Temer took office as President of Brazil in her place. 

Since her removal, Rousseff has continued to be an important figure in Brazilian politics.  She has actively participated in demonstrations and social movements in defense of democracy and human rights. 

Dilma Rousseff, despite the criticism and challenges throughout her political career, has left a legacy as the first female president of Brazil and as an advocate for the rights of women and the most disadvantaged.  Her story is an example of perseverance and struggle for social justice in Brazil.
Enrique Pe\u00f1a Nieto:
Enrique Peña Nieto was born on July 20, 1966 in Atlacomulco, State of Mexico.  Coming from a middle-class family, Peña Nieto showed interest in politics and communication from a young age.

In 2005, Peña Nieto was elected as the governor of the State of Mexico, a position he held for six years.  During his term, he implemented various reforms in education, health, and public security, managing to reduce violence rates in the state and improve the quality of life for citizens.
